tit.e: Ryoji (orders issued by princes, empresses, etc.)
Ryoji (orders issued by princes, empresses, etc.)
tit.cmt: 以下説明が続くので、説明は削除しました。

sen.j: 令旨（りょうじ）とは、律令制のもとで出された、皇太子・三后（太皇太后・皇太后・皇后）の命令を伝えるために出した文書。
sen.e: Ryoji refers to a document issued under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code by princes, empresses, etc.) for conveying orders of princes and three sango (Grand Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager, and Empress).

Ryoji refers to a document issued under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code by princes, empresses, etc.) for conveying orders of princes and three sango (Grand Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager, and Empress).

Ryoji refers to a document issued under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code by princes, empresses, etc.) for conveying orders of princes and three sango (Grand Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager, and Empress).

sen.j: 中国（唐）では皇太子の命令を伝える文書を令といったが、それが日本に伝わった。
sen.e: In China (Tong), a document intended to convery orders of princes was called ryo, which was introduced into Japan.

sen.j: 日本では皇太子の命令を伝える文書を令旨といい、太皇太后・皇太后・皇后の出す文書もこれに準じた。
sen.e: In Japan, such a document for conveying orders of princes came to be called ryoji, which also include documents issued by Grand Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager, and Empres.

sen.j: 平安時代中期以降は、皇太子・三后以外の皇族（女院・親王・諸王）のものも令旨と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: In and after the mid Heian period, ryoji started to cover documents issued by other imperial families (nyoin (a close female relative of the Emperor or a womwan of comparable standing), Princess, and Shoo (princes who didn't receive any proclamation to be an Imperial Prince) in addtion to princes and sango.

sen.j: 歴史上、有名な令旨としては、「源平の争乱」の際に、源氏挙兵の正当性を表すものとして発令された、「以仁王の令旨」がある。
sen.e: A historically famous ryoji is "Prince Mochihito's order" issued to justify the Genji's raising of the army during the Genpei War.
